captions.text: >> Jon: WELCOME TO THE DAILY

SHOW, MY NAME IS JON
STEWART.

WE GOT A PROGRAM FOR YOU
TONIGHT.

THIS IS-- THIS IS EXCITING,
ANNA KENDRICK, OH SHE'S ONE

OF OUR FAVORITES, SHE IS SO
GOOD. "INTO THE WOODS",

SHE IS GOING TO BE HERE, VERY
TALENTED.

BUT FIRST, YOU MAY HAVE BEEN
NOTICING THE

JUSTICE SYSTEM'S RECENT
CONSISTENT FAILURE TO INDICT

POLICE OFFICERS WHO HAVE
KILLED UNARMED BLACK MEN

HAS SPARKED PROTESTS ALL
OVER THE COUNTRY.

THE DEMONSTRATIONS HAVE
BEEN OVERWHELMINGLY
PEACEFUL.

WHICH MAKES IT VERY DIFFICULT
FOR PEOPLE TO COMPLAIN ABOUT
THEM.
DIFFICULT, NOT IMPOSSIBLE.

>> WE HAVE THE RIGHT TO
PROTEST, THEY GO ON THE

SIDEWALK AND MAKE NOISE AND
HOLD SIGNS AN LET PEOPLE
KNOW YOU DISAGREE.

BUT WHEN YOU BLOCK TRAFFIC,
THAT'S A FORM OF VIOLENCE.
>> Jon: YES!

THANK YOU, BLOCKING TRAFFIC
IS A FORM OF VIOLENCE.

HOW DARE THESE MARCHERS PUT
OUR STREETS IN SOME KIND

OF-- LET'S CALL IT A
CHOKEHOLD OF TRAFFIC.
HOW DARE THEY!

WOULDN'T HAVE ANYTHING TO
DO WITH THE STREETS BEING
BLACK, NOW, DOES IT?

YOU KNOW, IF YOU ARE THAT
CONVINCED THAT IMPEDING

MANHATTAN DRIVERS IS A FORM
OF VIOLENCE, WELL, I THINK IT'S

TIME TO INDICT THE NEW YORK
MARATHON.

THE MACY'S THANKSGIVING DAY
PARADE, THE PUERTO RICAN DAY

PARADE, THE GAY PRIDE PARADE,
THE ST. PATRICK'S DAY PARADE,

THE HALLOWEEN PARADE, THE GERMAN
AMERICAN STEUBEN PARADE OR ANY

RANDOM POP-UP STREET FAIR
SELLING MYSTERY MEATS AND

TUBE SOCKS, AND I HAVEN'T
EVEN GOTTEN TO THE MOST
VIOLENT OF OFFENDERS.

PLEASE, THAT TREE IS LIKE A
GLITTERING BERLIN WALL

PREVENTING ANY MOVEMENT FROM
EAST TO WEST.

MR. CLAUS, TEAR DOWN THAT
TREE.

(APPLAUSE)
BUT IT'S ONE THING FOR

PROTESTORS, IT'S ONE THING
FOR PROTESTORS TO DO

VIOLENCE TO OUR CITY STREETS
AND TRAFFIC.

IT IS QUITE ANOTHER FOR THEM
TO USE EXCESSIVE FORCE
AGAINST CHRISTMAS ITSELF.
>> IT IS CREATING HAVOC.

AND WE'VE GOT TWO WEEKS BEFORE
CHRISTMAS.

DO YOU THINK THIS IS GOING
TO HAVE SOME IMPACT-- I MEAN

WHO WANTS TO GO SHOPPING AT
MACY'S WHEN THIS IS GOING ON.

>> Jon: PROTESTORS PREVENTING
PEOPLE FROM SHOPPING AT MACY'S.

I HOPE THESE SHOPPERS SHALL
OVERCOME.

NOW THAT'S-- YES, I CAN'T
BUY-- YES, YES, BLACK FRIDAY
MATTERS.
IT DOES.

THE PROTESTS HAVE EVEN
SPILLED OVER INTO
PROFESSIONAL SPORTS.

>> ATHLETES DONNING T-SHIRTS
EXPRESSING A DESIRE FOR
JUSTICE.

NOW LAST TIME I CHECKED,
T-SHIRTS DON'T BLOCK
TRAFFIC.

THEY DON'T PREVENT FROM YOU
SHOPPING AT MACY'S.

THEY SHOULD BE A PERFECTLY
ACCEPTABLE WAY TO EXPRESS

ONE'S FEELINGS ABOUT
POLITICAL ISSUES.

>> I WONDERED TO MYSELF,
WHAT IF LEBRON JAMES INSTEAD

HAD A SHIRT BE A BETTER
FATHER TO YOUR DAD.

I MEAN BE A BETTER FATHER TO
YOUR SON.
RAISE YOUR CHILDREN.

THOSE DIFFICULT ISSUES ARE
NOT BEING DEALT WITH BY THE
BLACK COMMUNITY.

>> Jon: WELL, BE A BETTER
FATHER.

LEBRON ACTUALLY LIVES THAT
MESSAGE.

AND IF HE WANTS ADVICE ON
SHIRTS I'M SURE HE WILL ASK
SOMEONE WHO WEARS ONE.
BUT POINT TAKEN.

POINT TAKEN-- NO, NOW-- WE
HAVE TO RESPECT THE POINT.

I MEAN OBVIOUSLY ONE OF
THESE TWO MEN HAS FIVE KIDS

IN VARIOUS LOCATIONS BY
MULTIPLE BABY MOMMAS.

AND THE OTHER IS LEBRON
JAMES.

BUT OBVIOUSLY, GERALDO ISN'T
THE ONLY ONE UPSET ABOUT
THE T-SHIRT PROTESTS.

>> THE CLEVELAND POLICE
UNION DEMANDS AN APOLOGY
FROM THE CLEVELAND BROWNS.

ONE OF THE BROWNS PLAYERS
ANDREW HAWKINS WALKED ONTO

THE FIELD ON SUNDAY WEARING
THIS T-SHIRT.

IT CALLED FOR JUSTICE FOR
TAMIR RICE.

THE POLICE UNION SAYS THE
TEAM SHOULD STICK TO WHAT IT

KNOWS BEST AND THAT WOULD BE
FOOTBALL.
>> Jon: WAIT.

STICK TO WHAT THEY
KNOW BEST FOOTBALL?

WE'RE TALKING
ABOUT THE CLEVELAND BROWNS,
RIGHT?

I MEAN--
(LAUGHTER)

RANDOM CHEAP SHOT AT THE
CLEVELAND BROWNS.

LOOK, IT'S NOT AS IF THERE
ISN'T A CONVERSATION

WARRANTED ABOUT THE
CLEVELAND POLICE DEPARTMENT
BY T-SHIRT OR OTHERWISE.

>> CLEVELAND'S POLICE FORCE
HAS BEEN UNDER FEDERAL
INVESTIGATION SINCE 2013.

THE JUSTICE DEPARTMENT
EXAMINED OVER 600 CASES

>> THE CLEVELAND
DIVISION OF PUBLIC POLICE

ENGAGES IN A PATTERN AND
PRACTICE OF USING EXCESSIVE
FORCE.

>> Jon: WELL, I GUESS THE
ONLY DIFFERENCE IS WHEN

FOOTBALL PLAYERS USE
EXCESSIVE FORCE, THEY GET
PENALIZED.

AND IF THAT-- 15 YARDS, AM I
WRONG?

(LAUGHTER)
AND IF THAT FOOTBALL

PLAYER DISRESPECTED THE
OFFICER WHO SHOT AND KILLED

TAMIR RICE, A 12-YEAR-OLD
HOLD A BB GUN WITHIN 2

SECONDS OF ROLLING UP ON HIM,
YOU SHOULD HEAR WHAT THIS

OFFICER'S FORMER
EMPLOYER SAID ABOUT HIM.

>> AT HIS PREVIOUS JOB THE
INDEPENDENCE POLICE DEPARTMENT,
OFFICER LOEHMANN'S PERSONNEL

RECORDS SHOW HE WAS IN THE
PROCESS OF BEING FIRED.

HIS SUPERVISOR DESCRIBING AN
EMOTIONAL MELTDOWN.

>> ADDING THAT HE WOULD NOT
BE ABLE TO SUBSTANTIALLY

COPE OR MAKE GOOD DECISIONS
DURING OR RESULTING FROM ANY
OTHER STRESSFUL SITUATION.

>> BUT THE CLEVELAND POLICE
NEVER ASKED TO SEE LOEHMANN'S
PERSONNEL RECORDS.

>> Jon: EVEN WITHOUT READING
HIS RECORD, THEY SHOULD HAVE

REALIZED SOMETHING WAS WRONG
WHEN THEY MET HIM.
>> THESE BABIES CAN GO OFF.

>> Jon: SO WHY SHOULDN'T-- WHY
SHOULDN'T THE CLEVELAND

BROWNS OR ANY OTHER
CLEVELAND CITIZEN TALK ABOUT

A HUGE AND ULTIMATELY FATAL
DEPARTMENTAL SCREW UP?

>> THE CLEVELAND POLICE
UNION HEADS ARGUED ATHLETES

HAD NO BUSINESS WEIGHING IN
AT ALL SAYING QUOTE IT IS

PRETTY PATHETIC WHEN ATHLETES
THINK THEY KNOW THE LAW.

>> Jon: I GET WHERE YOU'RE
COMING FROM.
DUMB OLD FOOTBALL PLAYER.

I CATCH A BALL WHILE WEARING
A SHELL ON MY HEAD!
I MEAN SERIOUSLY.

WHAT MAKES THIS GUY THINK
HE'S GOT AN OPINION WORTH

SHARING ON THIS COMPLICATED
ISSUE?

AND THAT HE, THE FOOTBALL
PLAYER, SHOULDN'T APOLOGIZE.

>> MY MOMMA'S TAUGHT ME MY
ENTIRE LIFE TO RESPECT LAW
ENFORCEMENT.

I HAVE FAMILY, CLOSE FRIENDS
WHO ARE INCREDIBLE POLICE
OFFICERS.

AND I TELL THEM ALL THE TIME
HOW THEY ARE MUCH BRAVER

THAN ME FOR IT. UNFORTUNATELY,
MY MOM ALSO TAUGHT ME THAT

JUST AS THERE ARE GOOD
POLICE OFFICERS, THERE ARE

SOME NOT SO GOOD POLICE
OFFICERS THAT WOULD ASSUME

THE WORST OF ME WITHOUT
KNOWING ANYTHING ABOUT ME,
FOR REASONS I CAN'T CONTROL.

TO ME JUSTICE MEANS THAT THE
INNOCENT SHOULD BE FOUND
INNOCENT.

IT MEANS THAT THOSE WHO DO
WRONG SHOULD GET THEIR DUE
PUNISHMENT.

ULTIMATELY, IT MEANS FAIR
TREATMENT.

SO A CALL FOR JUSTICE
SHOULDN'T OFFEND OR
DISRESPECT ANYBODY.

A CALL FOR JUSTICE SHOULDN'T
WARRANT AN APOLOGY.

(APPLAUSE)
>> Jon: WE'LL BE RIGHT BACK.

title: The Daily Show - Rage Against the Rage Against the Machine

comments.author: Mi Horrorshow

comments.text:
So he shows video clips of people lighting fires in the streets and 
breaking down windows? Tell me that's perfectly ok and people aren't 
getting hurt.

Don't get me wrong, high five on the rest of the video and Fox is pretty 
stupid for whining about CHRISTMAS SHOPPING. But there's a serious problem 
when people clog up streets to protest; you arbitrarily punish a bunch of 
people who are just trying to get to work and have families to feed (black, 
white, same deal) most of which agree with you that there's a serious 
problem with both racial profiling and police brutality.

And even then, if you're going to raise all hell, wouldn't it be smart to 
actually do it at the police department or the courthouse? Things are 
leading up to Watts '92 all over again where communities are being 
destroyed, innocent lives are being caught up in the crossfire, and 
politicians are cashing in on the chaos to get more funding for the 
offending cops to "educate" (arm) them.

The president himself used Eric Gardner's death not to limit the authority 
police have to arrest and assault people for no good reason, but to give 
them cameras that they may or may not experience "technical difficulties" 
with next time they want to kick some ass. How about a constitutional 
amendment that forbids laws prohibiting surveillance of police or filming 
in courtrooms? That will go a long way toward curbing racism and brutality 
in the justice system.﻿

comments.author: David Hoffnung

comments.text:
+Antonio C-P I also want to point out a different thing... I think the 
reason that I and a bunch of other people enjoy Comedy Central's silly 
editorial "news" programs more than Newscorp's inflammatory editorial 
"news" programs has more to do with the flavor of the content than the 
content itself.  CC raises heavy issues with a light heart.  They make 
infuriating stuff hilarious - and it's funny when they're wrong, too.  Fox, 
instead, uses emotions of fear, anger, and the in-group mentality to 
deliver their content.  It makes me physically upset to watch programming 
like that - and yet, I can totally deal with some goofy guy making a joke 
about horrible violence in the middle-east.  I think having different 
voices (the more the merrier!) out there is essential for the American 
Experiment to work out - but I also think that the voices capable of humor 
and subtlety catch the ears of many people easier than otherwise.  Flies 
and honey and all that.
comments.author: David Hoffnung

comments.text:
+Antonio C-P Truth.  Almost the entirety of popular "news media" on "both" 
sides is just frothing sensationalism.  It isn't Fox's "conservative" 
stance that bothers me so much as how they go about it - and in this way, 
they stand out to me the most.  That said, the rest aren't really any 
better.  The best recommendation I could make to anyone is just to get your 
news from multiple sources, trying to include dryly factual reports in the 
mix with all the editorials - and draw your own conclusions from the mix 
while being aware of the biases held by each source.
comments.author: David Hoffnung

majority of citizens see fit. I still don't think everybody knows enough 
about the situation to make judgement, but there still is a serious issue 
going on with inequality.﻿

comments.text:
+10grandredline, " *This is a democracy. The courts are responsible for 
interpreting the laws as the majority of citizens see fit.*" The last time 
I checked, courts must apply the laws independently of any citizens 
opinions. Democracy means that citizens can elect representatives in charge 
to make the laws or in charge to apply them, or that citizens can vote on 
which laws become instantiated.
comments.author: Caren Ami

comments.text:
+Andrew Barrow the purpose of law is to stop the instantanius wims of the

comments.author: Antonio C-P

comments.text:
+Antonio C-P I'm not sure this is entirely on the mark either. The opinions 
of people naturally shape laws over time, however, traditions of law allow 
us to logically negotiate these changes without endangering concepts we 
find important (cf. the rights of minorities). We can talk about law 
without resorting to vaguely misanthropic Burkean rhetoric

comments.text:
I've been affected by racism too and I'm white. Whether you realize it or 
not, race relations had come a hell of a long way from the fifties and 
sixties...I was there.

White people and black people voted Obama in, there is no question about 
that. I thought it was finally over, dead and buried. Obama has done the 
worst damage that I've seen since the sixties by NOT saying anything to 
bring us together.

Ferguson was Ferguson. Trust the truth or trust the BS artists, all the 
justice ever to be served there is done, gone and buried. The same white 
people who voted in Obama were still there, in any crowd watching. When 
Obama did NOTHING and instead chummed up with race baiter Sharpton and 
Islam, race relations gains over the years began to slide back. Regardless 
of how people feel, these are the facts.

Now, whites are being attacked by blacks constantly and put on youtube 
etc...whites are most likely going to start attacking back. Then, we're ALL 
back in the fifties and sixties. We as whites need to police whites. Blacks 
need to police blacks also. Muslims are not policing murdering Muslims, so 
they are ALL viewed as evil. 

I visit liberal CNN, and their take is there is no conservative who isn't 
racist. That's a dumbass statement that creates division.

Fox doesn't equate that, so I had to look for less professional 
conservative sights, and they espouse that liberals are racist, and enjoy 
the "divide and conquer" strategy...another dumbass statement.

It's going to come down to us. Either we knock this shit off together, or 
it continues to tear us apart and create a miserable USA for the following 
generations.

By the way, Europe isn't laughing at us for racism. Whites and blacks there 
are seeing a rise in racism as well as Europeans and Middle Easterners 
duking it out...there will be some major race related uprisings there if 
they can't get a hold of it.

Also, the US still has more weapons per capita than Switzerland. Do some 
research...see all perspectives...get back to me if I'm wrong...warning...I 
am very good at research though.﻿

comments.text:
So this is the conclusion I've came to about racist prejudice people after 
all of these years researching. Racist people are trapped in an imaginary 
world, where they think that everyone else who is different from them, is 
below them. They're trapped in their own bubble, isolated from the rest of 
society. They always assume the worst in people that are different, they 
always look for the negatives, and they come to believe that they're 
superior to everyone else. The only difference between a white man and a 
black man, or a Hispanic man, Asian man, etc, is their genetic makeup, (and 
skin pigmentation), the only 2 things that NOBODY has any control over, 
just exactly like what the young man said in the video at the end.  And 
whenever they come across someone who's different from them, their 
immediate thought, is that the person is an enemy, when in reality, the 
truth is the only enemy is themselves; because they can't escape their own 
ignorant and negative way of thinking.﻿

kills an innocent of any color and isn't held accountable.  This situation 
blew up because of existing, underlying racial tension - but at least for

here.  Armed officers should be held to a higher standard than the average 
citizen - not a lower one.  Even if an officer kills someone accidentally, 
there should still be some level of accountability - not just some 
statement that says they acted appropriately and everything is okay - never 
mind an innocent child got blown away by an adult, etc.

comments.text:
+CCJJ160Channels There is no "they" in reality. There are organized groups 
sharing an agenda, and there are some people that tend to vote republican, 
and some who tend to vote democrat, but there really is no "they" in 
reality. There are different points of view and even some frightening 
people running for office, but no "they". There are people fighting to the 
death against who "they" are. I'm just lucky it's not me, and if it's you, 
I'm truly sorry. We are all just people influenced by our 
surroundings. Often the need to fit in and be important overcomes common 
sense that we lose sight of others' basic human rights. Tribalism is part 
of us all. We MUST learn to control it if we are to survive. This starts by 
seeing it, understanding it, and controlling it.

comments.author: Bernadette Kerr

comments.text:
+Bernadette Kerr
I wasn't nit picking, I was offering an example. My point isn't the same 
thing you're talking about. What I'm referring to is when conservatives 
(not necessarily the media) are censored because of their opinions. A man 
who owns a cake shop is sued when he dares to say he doesn't support gay 
marriage and refuses, on the grounds of a moral objection, to endorse the 
practice by baking the wedding cake. This is a form of censorship: deeming 
his opinions hateful, and therefore suing him out of his business.
comments.author: Christian Smith

comments.text:
+Christian Smith That's a very small nit you are picking there sir, most of 
the "opinions" they leave out are to stupid to be deserving of attention. 
And as for the way the right deals in facts, well, Billy 'O still has a job.
comments.author: Bernadette Kerr

comments.text:
+basilmemories The original subject was that guy, but this went on a 
tangent and now it's about which is more extreme, censoring freedom of 
speech, or wiretapping+TSC? The thing is humiliation and torture is still 
not limiting freedom of speech. Limiting freedom of speech(I'm talking on a 
wide scale here) is what leads to tyranny(communism has made it pretty 
clear in the past).

I'm not talking about Youtube comments, I think you misunderstood. It's not 
like the US government has passed a law that literally limits freedom of 
speech. I'm not Tumblr, Youtube comments aren't that big of a deal. If 
you're comparing this to Youtube comments, then yeah I agree with you 100%.

The original comment was claiming conservatives are hypocrites on freedom 
of speech, and my complaint was he was basing that off a couple people on 
Fox News(or practically everyone on Fox News). A lot of conservatives don't 
even like Fox News in the first place.
comments.author: Jake Milliken

comments.text:
+Jake Milliken  Your words: "I'm a conservative and will always defend 
freedom of speech, no matter how much I disagree with the statement. Stop 
making stereotypical assumptions based on one guy."
My response: "What about making those assumptions based on the Patriot act 
and other bush-era laws?"
your response: "Those aren't as extreme though, [...]"

The original subject is calling out one guy for being an awful and 
dismissive about legal protests. how is that MORE extreme than "if we 
suspect you for any reason or say something that we don't like, we're going 
to wiretap your place and/or do humiliating things to you at the airport, 
if we let you fly at all". like call me crazy, but somehow that seems worse 
than people getting on any given fox news anchors' back for them saying 
kinda racist bs, but ultimately not invading their privacy or personal 
lives.

Or did I miss the memo where youtube comments are the literal worst thing 
you could do to someone now?
comments.author: basilmemories

comments.text:
+basilmemories "Aren't *as* extreme"

That as means it can still be extreme, just not as extreme as the original 
subject. Straight limiting freedom of speech isn't in that law. Privacy 
invading tactics and sketchy TSC tactics are the only thing in that list. 
Limiting someone the ability to fly in a country is not the same as 
limiting if they can say something or not. Being put on a no fly list is 
not censorship or restraint, as long as no censorship or restraint occurs 
within the actual speech part, then it is not limiting freedom of speech. 
Although those TSC tactics are pretty close behind limiting freedom of 
speech.
comments.author: Jake Milliken

comments.text:
+Jake Milliken "Aren't as extreme"

Okay, just checking, which part of these aren't as extreme? Is it the part 
that widely expanded use of wiretapping, email snooping, camera use, and 
other privacy-invading procedures? Is it the part where the permission to 
gain access to those methods became amazingly easy for law enforcement 
officials, even when the evidence for the procedure could be mighty shaky? 
Is it the part where people got on the no fly list just for being Muslim or 
criticizing the government?

Oh, there we go, perhaps it's in the airline security that's okay by you. 
So for that is it the cases where women have been systematically and 
sexually harrassed by tsa officials? Would it be the case where a woman had 
to drink her own breast milk? Or is it the time where a man was rectally 
probed for no good reason? Lemme guess, it's all the cases of people being 
held for hours without ability to contact anyone and occasionally 
assaulted. I bet it's that one, that clearly can't be reaching.

Like c'mon, you can't say that those politics smell like roses.
comments.author: basilmemories
